questions.text: If the mean of a normal distribution is 20 and its standard deviation is 5, then 95% of the data lie within which of the following ranges?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

95% of data in a normal distribution lies within ±2 standard deviations from the mean.

  • Given mean (μ) = 20
  • Standard deviation (σ) = 5
  • Range covering 95% of data = μ ± 2σ = 20 ± 10
  • Therefore, 95% of values fall between 10 and 30

Related Important Points:

  • 68%of data lies within ±1 SD (15 to 25 in this case)
  • 95%of data lies within ±2 SD (10 to 30)
  • 7%of data lies within ±3 SD (5 to 35)
  • This is known as the Empirical Ruleor 68-95-99.7 Rule

Explanation of other options:

15.0 -25.0 (Option A): Represents ±1 SD, which only covers 68% of data

10.2 - 29.9 (Option B): Close to ±2 SD, but not the exact symmetric interval

7.1 - 32.9 (Option C): Closer to ±2.8 SD, which corresponds to nearly 99.5% of the data

Key Takeaway:

In a normal distribution, 95% of values fall within ±2 SDof the mean.

Survival times following a heart transplant
Heights of individuals in the population
The ages of first-year medical PG students

questions.text: Select all of the following variables that are likely to follow a normal distribution:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Height is a classical example of a variable that follows a normal distribution in large populations.

  • According to the Central Limit Theorem, when a variable is influenced by multiple small, independent factors (genetic + environmental), the resulting distribution tends to be normal.
  • Height fits this profile well it is continuous and influenced by multiple factors, and therefore exhibits a bell-shaped distribution.

Explanation of other options:

The number of hospital attendances (Option A): Count data, often follows Poisson or skewed distribution, not normal.

Survival times (Option B): Usually follow a right-skewed or exponential distribution, not normal.

Ages of PG students (Option D): In a selected group, age is often clustered and may not be normally distributed.

Key Takeaway:

Only variables like height, influenced by many independent factors, are likely to follow a normal distribution in the general population.

questions.text: If the birth weight of each of the babies born in a hospital in a day is found to be 2.8 kg, then the standard deviation of this sample will be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Standard deviation reflects how much each value in a dataset deviates from the mean. If all values are the same, then there is no deviation, and the SD is 0.

  • In this case, every baby weighs exactly 8 kg, so:
    • Mean = 2.8 kg
    • All individual values = 2.8 kg
    • Deviation of each value from mean = 0
  • Hence, the sum of squared deviations is 0, and the SD = 0

Key Takeaway:

If all observations in a dataset are identical, the standard deviation is always 0.

questions.text: Standard deviation of means is a measure of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard deviation of means, also called the standard error of the mean (SEM), quantifies the variability of sample means around the population mean.

  • It reflects the sampling error, i.e., the error that arises due to taking different samples from the same population.
  • SEM = SD / √n, where SD is the standard deviation of the sample, and n is the sample size.
  • As sample size increases, SEM decreases, indicating greater precision of the estimate.

Explanation of other options:

Non-sampling errors (Option A): Errors in data collection or processing; not related to sampling variability

Random errors (Option C): Affect individual measurements, not sample means specifically

Conceptual errors (Option D): Errors in understanding or application of concepts; unrelated to SEM

Key Takeaway:

Standard error of the mean measures sampling error the variation of sample means around the true population mean.

questions.text: A researcher collects as many samples as possible from a population and plots a line using the mean values of those samples. What is this line called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When a researcher takes multiple samples from a population and plots their means, the resulting plot is known as a sampling diagram. This represents the distribution of sample means, a concept central to sampling theory.

  • This is foundational in understanding the Central Limit Theorem, which states that the distribution of sample means tends to follow a normal distribution as the number of samples increases, regardless of the population distribution.
  • The line or curve drawn through these sample means reflects the sampling distribution of the mean.

Explanation of other options:

Population diagram (Option A): Not a standard term; population data is not represented by this sampling approach.

Parameter diagram (Option B): No such term in statistics; parameters are constants, not graphed as distributions.

Sample diagram (Option C): Generic and undefined; may refer to a graph of raw sample data, not aggregated sample means.

Key Takeaway:

A sampling diagram illustrates the distribution of sample means and forms the basis of inferential statistics.

questions.text: According to the Empirical Rule, what percentage of data should lie within the normal limits (±2 standard deviations from the mean) in a normal distribution?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Empirical Rule (also known as the 68-95-99.7 rule or three-sigma rule) describes how data is distributed in a normal distribution:

  • 68% of values lie within ±1 SD from the mean
  • 95% of values lie within ±2 SD from the mean → this is referred to as the normal limits
  • 99.7% of values lie within ±3 SD from the mean

Thus, 95% is the percentage of values that fall within normal limits.

Explanation of other options:

75% (Option A): Not part of the empirical rule-this figure is irrelevant in this context

68% (Option B): Refers to ±1 SD, not the normal limit

99.7% (Option D): Refers to ±3 SD, not typically considered the normal limit

Key Takeaway:

According to the empirical rule, 95% of data lies within the normal limit (±2 SD) in a normal distribution.

questions.text: Among 100 women with an average hemoglobin of 10 gm%, the standard deviation is 1. What is the standard error of the mean?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To calculate the standard error of the mean (SEM), which represents the variability of sample means around the population mean, you use the formula:

SEM= Standard Deviation/ sqrt of Sample Size

Given:

  • Standard deviation (SD) = 1
  • Sample size = 100

SEM= 1/ √100 = 0.1

So, the correct answer is b. 0.1

The standard error of the mean (SEM) quantifies how much the sample mean is expected to vary from the population mean. It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation of the sample by the square root of the sample size.

  • SEM gives an idea of how much the sample mean varies from the population mean
  • SEM is always smaller than SD

Key Takeaway:

The standard error of the mean is calculated as SD / √n and is a measure of precision of the sample mean.

questions.text: What is the probability that the confounding factor fall to the right of 95%
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To understand the probability that a confounding factor falls to the right of 95% :

  • Confounding Factor: In statistics and research, a confounding factor is an extraneous variable that correlates with both the independent variable and the dependent variable. It can distort the relationship between the two variables under study.
  • Falls to the Right of 95%: This implies that the confounding factor has a value greater than the 95th percentile of its distribution.

Now, the 95th percentile is a value below which 95% of the data falls. Therefore, if the confounding factor falls to the right of the 95th percentile, it means it's in the top 5% of the distribution.

The option "1 in 40" indicates that the probability of the confounding factor falling to the right of 95% is 1 out of 40, or 1/40. This means that if you randomly select a value from the distribution of the confounding factor, there's a 1/40 chance that it will fall to the right of the 95th percentile.

Explanation of other options:

1 in 5 (Option A): This would imply a probability of 1/5 or 20%, which is much higher than the probability of falling to the right of the 95th percentile.

1 in 15 (Option B): Similar to the above, this would imply a probability of 1/15 or approximately 6.67%, which is also higher than the probability of interest.

1 in 20 (Option C): Again, this would imply a probability of 1/20 or 5%, which is exactly the probability of falling below the 95th percentile, not to the right of it.

Key Takeaway:

A 1 in 40 probability corresponds to the extreme right tail of a normal distribution, useful in identifying rare confounding outliers.

questions.text: A parameter is a measure which is computed from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A parameter is a numerical value that describes a characteristic of an entire population, such as:

  • Population mean (μ)
  • Population standard deviation (σ)
  • Population proportion (P)

These values are typically unknown and are estimated using sample statistics derived from a representative subset of the population.

Explanation of other options:

Sample data (Option B): Used to compute statistics, not parameters

Test statistic (Option C): Calculated from sample data for hypothesis testing; not a parameter

Key Takeaway:

Parameters are descriptive measures calculated from the entire population, while statistics describe samples.

choices.text: The intervals are larger with smaller sample size
95% confidence interval means that 95% of all observed values in population fall within that interval.
In an odds ratio, if the 95% confidence interval includes unity, then no significant difference may apply

questions.text: Which of the following statements about confidence intervals is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 95% confidence interval (CI) represents the range within which the true population parameter is expected to lie in 95% of the samples drawn from the population-not 95% of the population data points.

  • Correct interpretation: If you repeat sampling many times, 95% of the confidence intervals constructed from those samples would contain the true parameter.
  • It does not mean that 95% of individual data values lie within the interval.

Explanation of other options:

The intervals are larger with smaller sample size (Option A): True - smaller sample size → greater variability → wider CI

In an odds ratio, if the 95% confidence interval includes unity, then no significant difference may apply (Option C): True - if the 95% CI of an odds ratio includes 1, the association is not statistically significant

Key Takeaway:

Confidence intervals describe the precision of estimates and the likelihood of containing the true parameter, not the distribution of population values.

questions.text: If a distribution is abnormally tall and sharply peaked, it is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A leptokurtic distribution is abnormally tall and peaked with heavy tails, indicating higher kurtosis than a normal (mesokurtic) distribution.

  • Kurtosis refers to the sharpness or flatness of a distribution's peak.
  • Leptokurtic curves have narrower peaks and fatter tails, showing more extreme values.
  • This makes them more concentrated around the mean with occasional outliers.

Explanation of other options:

Pyrokurtic (Option B): Not a valid statistical term; irrelevant in this context

Platykurtic (Option C): Flatter and broader curve, opposite of what's described

Mesokurtic (Option D): Normal distribution (e.g., bell curve), not abnormally peaked

Key Takeaway:

A leptokurtic distribution is tall, sharply peaked, and has heavier tails, indicating high kurtosis.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 95% confidence interval means that if we were to take repeated samples and calculate a confidence interval from each, then 95% of those intervals would contain the true population mean.

  • Thus, for any single sample, there is a 5% chance that its calculated confidence interval does not include the population mean.
  • This does not mean we're 95% sure about the sample mean or that the population mean is exactly equal to μ1.

A 95% confidence interval implies that there is a 5% chance the true population mean lies outside the calculated range.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the similarities and differences in the three normal distributions shown in the figure (not displayed here)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The figure typically referred to in this context (as shown in Park’s textbook) depicts three normal curves that are centered at the same point (i.e., same mean and median) but have different spreads, indicating different standard deviations.

  • A wider curve indicates a larger standard deviation, while a narrower curve indicates a smaller standard deviation.
  • Since the central location remains unchanged (same peak), the mean and median are the same across all distributions.

Key Takeaway:

In normal curves with same center but different spread, the mean and median are constant, but standard deviation varies.

questions.text: What is the algebraic relationship between variance and standard deviation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard deviation (SD) and variance are both measures of dispersion, but they differ in their mathematical relationship:

  • Variance (σ²) is the average of the squared deviations from the mean.
  • Standard deviation (σ) is the square root of the variance:

σ=√σ2

  • This transformation brings the measure back into the original units of the data.

Key Takeaway:

The standard deviation is the square root of the variance, providing a more interpretable measure of spread in original units.

questions.text: Which of the following are considered measures of variability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All three listed options range, mean deviation, and standard deviation are measures of variability (or dispersion), describing the spread of data in a dataset.

  • Range:
    • Difference between the maximum and minimum
    • Simplest measure of spread, but sensitive to outliers.
  • Mean Deviation (MD):
    • Also called average deviation.
    • Average of the absolute differences from the mean.
    • Gives a sense of how much data points deviate on average.
  • Standard Deviation (SD):
    • Most widely used measure of variability.
    • Considers the square of deviations from the mean.
    • Used in most statistical procedures including confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.

Key Takeaway:

All of the listed options are valid measures of dispersion, with standard deviation being the most statistically robust and commonly used.

Explanation:

Confidence limits are calculated using the mean and the standard error. The standard error represents the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of a statistic (such as the mean). It quantifies the variability of sample estimates and is used to calculate confidence intervals. Confidence limits, often referred to as confidence intervals, are constructed around the sample mean using the standard error to provide a range within which the population parameter (such as the population mean) is likely to fall.

  • Hence, both the mean and the standard error are required for this calculation.

Explanation of other options:

Mean and standard deviation (Option A): SD reflects spread of raw data, but SE reflects precision of the mean, which is used for CI

Median and standard deviation (Option B): Not appropriate for CI; median is non-parametric

Median (Option C): Cannot be used alone to calculate confidence intervals

Key Takeaway:

Confidence intervals are calculated using the mean and standard error, not the standard deviation or median.

questions.text: Two variables can be plotted together using:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A scatter diagram (scatter plot) is specifically designed to plot two continuous variables together, allowing us to:

  • Visualize potential correlations or associations
  • Detect positive, negative, or no correlation
  • Analyze linear or non-linear relationships

Each point on the graph corresponds to a pair of values (x, y) for the two variables under consideration.

Explanation of other options:

Pie chart (Option A): Categorical, single-variable distribution only

Histogram (Option B): Shows frequency of one variable; can't compare two

Frequency polygon (Option C): Like histogram but smoother; still for one variable

Key Takeaway:

A scatter diagram is the standard graph used to simultaneously plot two variables and study their relationship.

questions.text: A measure of location that divides the distribution in the ratio of 3:1 is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The third quartile (Q3) marks the point below which 75% of the observations lie, effectively dividing the data in a 3:1 ratio (i.e., three parts below and one part above).

Explanation of other options:

Median (Option A): Divides the distribution into two equal halves (50:50), not 3:1.

First quartile (Option B): Divides the distribution into 1:3 ratio, with 25% below and 75% above.

Mode (Option D): Most frequent value; it doesn't divide the dataset into fixed ratios.

Key Takeaway:

The third quartile (Q3) divides the dataset into a 3:1 ratio, placing 75% of the values below it.

choices.text: Chance of death by using statin is 50% less, and true effect on population is between 60% and 40%
Chance of death by using statin is 50% more, and true effect on population is between 60% and 80%
Chance of death by using statin is 50% less, and true effect on population is between 60% and 20%
Chance of death by using statin is 60% less, and true effect on population is between 60% and 80%

questions.text: A clinical trial was conducted to compare the efficacy of statin vs. placebo. The Odds Ratio (OR) was 0.5, and the 95% Confidence Interval (CI) was 0.4-0.6. What is the correct interpretation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An odds ratio of 0.5 indicates a 50% reduction in the odds of death in the statin group compared to placebo.

  • A 95% confidence interval of 4 to 0.6 means the true effect size lies between a 60% and 40% reduction in odds.
  • Since the CI does not include 1, the result is statistically significant.
  • This interpretation aligns with both the point estimate (OR 0.5) and the CI limits.

Explanation of other options:

Chance of death by using statin is 50% more, and true effect on population is between 60% and 80% (Option B): OR of 0.5 means reduction, not increase; "50% more" is incorrect.

Chance of death by using statin is 50% less, and true effect on population is between 60% and 20% (Option C): Misinterprets the lower CI bound; it's 0.4 (40%), not 20%.

Chance of death by using statin is 60% less, and true effect on population is between 60% and 80% (Option D): OR of 0.5 = 50% reduction, not 60%; also, CI is 0.4-0.6 (not 0.2 or 0.8).

Key Takeaway:

An OR of 0.5 with a 95% CI of 0.4-0.6 indicates a significant 50% reduction in odds, with the true population effect ranging from 40-60% reduction.
